sub_title: Sociologist studying Labour market Inequalities, Inclusion/Exclusion, Discrimination & Diversity
summary: Interests: Inequalities, inclusion / exclusion & diversity in the labour market, across ethnic (migrant background), gender & socio-economic lines; factors that affect those, in particular the role of discrimination, attitudes / stereotypes / bias, human capital & social capital, the institutional and cultural context and policies (e.g. at the workplace / country level). Expertise in quantitative research methods (in STATA/SPSS/R); data collection (surveys / experiments / vignettes / meta-analysis / interviews); broad teaching experience at BA, MA, REMA levels.

awards.title: Sociology teacher of the year, Utrecht University

authors.headline: Sociologist studying Labour market Inequalities, Inclusion/Exclusion, Discrimination & Diversity
Professor of Sociology at Utrecht University and NIDI
Senior Researcher at The Netherlands Institute for Social Research ¦ SCP

profile_positions.description:
RESEARCH: My research deals with inequalities, processes of inclusion and exclusion, and diversity in the labour market, with a focus on ethnic differences (or differences according to migration background), gender differences and/or differences across socio-economic groups. It is aimed at better understanding the prevalence and sources of such differences, focusing in particular on the role of attitudes or stereotypes, discrimination, human and social capital, and the cultural and institutional context (e.g. at the workplace and/or country level).

TEACHING: developing, coordination and/or teaching courses on Research Designs & Methods; Sociological Perspectives on Crime; various Student Research Projects; Thesis Supervision
profile_positions.title: Assistant professor, Department of Sociology

profile_positions.description: Working as a postdoctoral researcher on the project 'Craftsmanship as a solution to youth unemployment? The influence of the vocational orientation of education on the labor market integration of youth'. This project examines how the vocational specificity/orientation of individuals' skills, educational programs and educational systems affects the labor market outcomes of youth (with a focus on young people who followed  vocational education or training (VET)), and whether this varies under different macro-economic conditions.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
RESEARCH: labor market outcomes, ethnic/gender differences, explanations, discrimination & policies

TEACHING: developing, coordination and teaching for the courses introduction to sociology and sociological questions; contemporary sociological theories, coordination and supervision student research project on delinquency; supervision comparative research project (research master); tutoring bachelor and honours students
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

company.name: Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in the Humanities and Social Sciences (NIAS-KNAW)

profile_positions.company: Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in the Humanities and Social Sciences (NIAS-KNAW)
profile_positions.description: This research project focused on support for or opposition to various measures that can be taken by organizations to decrease discrimination or increase diversity. I investigated (1) to what extent there is support for or opposition to different types of antidiscrimination or diversity measures in the Netherlands and other European countries, and (2) who supports which measures to a greater or lesser extent.  In addition to its scientific contributions, this project has to potential to have a valuable societal impact by informing the current lively debate about ethnic hiring discrimination and how to reduce it. It can provide insights on where, for whom, under which conditions and for which policies support may be increased.
profile_positions.title: Instituut Gak Fellow

profile_positions.description:
RESEARCH: working on the project ‘Women in higher management positions'. This project first examines the number of women and men in higher management positions (i.e., with job authority) in the Netherlands and the changes therein over the past 25 years. Second, the gender gap in job authority in the Netherlands is compared to that in other European countries. Furthermore, the project examines who manages who; e.g., do women more often supervise women and do men more often supervise men? Finally, the project focuses on explaining gender differences in job authority, changes therein over time, and differences therein between countries. It pays attention to micro-level factors (like human capital, norms and ambitions), meso-level factors (like organization size, percentage of women in occupations and sector), and macro-level factors (like policies and culture). 

For more information on the project (in Dutch) see: www.instituutgak.nl/research_programs/vrouwen-in-hogere-managementposities/

The following website (in Dutch) with inspiration for policies to enhance womens' representation in (top) management positions was developed as part of this project: http://www.vrouwenaandetop.nu/
Also, this project not only resulted in several scientific articles, but also in two publications for a broader public ('De toename van vrouwen in leidinggevende functies' by Tanja van der Lippe, Anneke van Doorne Huiskes & Lieselotte Blommaert appeared in Economisch Statistische Berichten in 2014 and 'Interventies voor meer vrouwen aan de top: wat werkt en wat werkt niet?' by Mieke Zijlstra and Esther de Ruijter appeared in Tijdschrift voor HRM in 2016).

TEACHING: developing, coordination and teaching for several courses, supervising bachelor and master theses and tutoring (bachelor and master students in Sociology).
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral researcher

profile_positions.description: TEACHING at bachelor and master level at the department of Sociology, Utrecht University. Courses: sociological questions, introduction to sociology, public policy (analysis of policy processes), research project: orientation phase (theoretical introduction sociology of stratification and family & development and assessment of questionnaires), integration of ethnic minorities (research and policy). Other: supervision bachelor and master theses, tutor bachelor students.
profile_positions.title: Teacher

profile_positions.description:
RESEARCH: My dissertation (which I defended on 10 June 2013) dealt with ethnic discrimination in the labor market. This study examined the prevalence of ethnic doscrimination in recruitment in the Netherlands and investigated which individual and contextual conditions foster or hamper discrimination in recruitment. 

Using data from field and laboratory experiments, surveys and reaction time tests (IATs), this study provided strong evidence of ethnic discrimination in recruitment procedures in the Netherlands. Discrimination of both male and female minority applicants occurs across sectors and occupational levels. During economic recessions discrimination appears to occur more often. Not all people are euqally likely to discriminate. Those who have more positive interethnic contacts and those with higher educational levels are less likely to discriminate, whereas males and those with religious (Christian) backgrounds are more likely to discriminate. Discrimination is not always the result of conscious (explicit) processes; having unconscious (implicit) negative associations with ethnic minorities also increases the likelihood of discriminating. 

My supervisors (promotor and co-promotor) were Prof. Dr. Frank van Tubergen and Dr. Marcel Coenders (Utrecht University, The Netherlands). 

TEACHING: Teaching several courses, supervising bachelor and master theses and tutoring bachelor students in Sociology (bachelor and master).
profile_positions.title: PhD student

profile_positions.company: The Netherlands Institute for Social Research (SCP)
profile_positions.description:
Research visit at the Netherlands Institute for Social Research (SCP) in The Hague, the Netherlands. 

Hosts: Iris Andriessen  & Jaco Dagevos

During my research visit at the Netherlands Institute for Social Research (SCP) I co-operated with Iris Andriessen and Jaco Dagevos on an article on regional variation in ethnic discrimination in recruitment and the role of regional features (e.g., economic conditions). For this article, I analyzed data from a field a experiment on ethnic discrimination in recruitment collected by the Netherlands Institute for Social Research. I enriched these data with information on geographical regions.
profile_positions.title: Visiting PhD student

profile_positions.description:
Student research and teaching assistant and the department of Sociology of the Radboud University in Nijmegen, The Netherlands. 

During my Bachelor in Sociology and Research Master in Social Cultural Science I worked as a student research assistant and teaching assistant, contributing to several projects and courses.
profile_positions.title: Student research and teaching assistent

company.name: SEOR BV, Erasmus School of Economics

profile_positions.company: SEOR BV, Erasmus School of Economics
profile_positions.description:
Internship at SEOR BV, Erasmus School of Economics, Rotterdam, The Netherlands

Host: Arie Gelderblom

During this internship I worked on a project called 'Costs and Benefits of Education via Information and Communication Technology'. My activities included data management, analyses and reporting of findings on the use of information and communication technology in education of adults.
profile_positions.title: Visiting student
